DataElement.preferredName: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form Questionnaire Shade in the Areas Where You Feel Pain Mark the Area of Most Intense Pain Diagram Total Count
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The total number of areas where pain was felt.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form Questionnaire Shade in the Areas Where You Feel Pain Mark the Area of Most Intense Pain Diagram
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A standardized survey originally developed and copyrighted by Charles S. Cleeland in 1991 which is used to evaluate the severity of a patient's pain and the impact that their pain has on their daily activities. This shorter version of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) is more useful for clinical trials, can be completed by the patient or in an interview format, and consists of only 9 questions most of which can be answered on a 0-10 rating scale._Instruction that an individual indicate by shading on a diagram of the body the area where they feel pain._Instruction that an individual mark on a diagram of the body the area where they feel the most intense pain._A drawing intended to explain how something works; a drawing showing the relation between the parts.

Cleeland in 1991 which is used to evaluate the severity of a patient's pain and the impact that their pain has on their daily activities. This shorter version of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) is more useful for clinical trials, can be completed by the patient or in an interview format, and consists of only 9 questions most of which can be answered on a 0-10 rating scale.
